unnormalised: ## My Brush with the Cashless Future (and Why I Still Carry ₹500)
normalised: ## My Brush with the Cashless Future (and Why I Still Carry Rupee Five Hundred)

unnormalised: Okay, so I'm trying to be one of those "modern" people who pay for everything with their phone. You know, scan the QR code, punch in the UPI pin, and *bam*, transaction done. The future is now, right? Except, the future keeps slapping me in the face with the very real necessity of good old cash.
normalised: Okay, so I'm trying to be one of those "modern" people who pay for everything with their phone. You know, scan the Q-R code, punch in the U-P-I pin, and *bam*, transaction done. The future is now, right? Except, the future keeps slapping me in the face with the very real necessity of good old cash.

unnormalised: It all started last month. I was heading to the local sabzi mandi – the vibrant chaos of colours and smells is something no supermarket can replicate. I figured, I'd finally put my newfound digital wallet skills to the test. Confidently, I strolled through the stalls, picking out plump tomatoes and crisp bhindi.
normalised: It all started last month. I was heading to the local sabzi mandi – the vibrant chaos of colours and smells is something no supermarket can replicate. I figured, I'd finally put my newfound digital wallet skills to the test. Confidently, I strolled through the stalls, picking out plump tomatoes and crisp bhindi.

unnormalised: First vendor, the tomato wallah. Showed him my phone, ready to scan. "Bhaiya, UPI hai?" I asked, all casual. He squinted at me, wiped his brow with a grubby cloth, and shook his head. "Nahi beta, only cash." Okay, no biggie. Moved on to the bhindi stall. Same story. Cash only. By this point, my confidence was starting to wilt faster than the spinach on display.
normalised: First vendor, the tomato wallah. Showed him my phone, ready to scan. "Bhaiya, U-P-I hai?" I asked, all casual. He squinted at me, wiped his brow with a grubby cloth, and shook his head. "Nahi beta, only cash." Okay, no biggie. Moved on to the bhindi stall. Same story. Cash only. By this point, my confidence was starting to wilt faster than the spinach on display.

unnormalised: Then came the auto-rickshaw incident. After a long, sweaty day, I flagged down an auto. Showed him my destination, hopped in, and off we went. Reached my stop, pulled out my phone again. "Bhaiya, Google Pay?" He chuckled. "Madam, auto-rickshaw mein UPI kaun use karta hai? ₹80 ho gaye." Eighty rupees. Luckily, I remembered to grab *some* cash that morning, but it was a close call.

"Bhaiya, Google Pay?" He chuckled. "Madam, auto-rickshaw mein U-P-I kaun use karta hai? Rupee eighty ho gaye." Eighty rupees. Luckily, I remembered to grab *some* cash that morning, but it was a close call.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the local tea stall. Raju bhai's chai is legendary, a perfect blend of ginger and spices. But Raju bhai is a traditionalist. He believes in the clink of coins, not the beep of a phone. A piping hot cup of chai is a steal at just ₹10, but only if you've got the exact change.
normalised: And don't even get me started on the local tea stall. Raju bhai's chai is legendary, a perfect blend of ginger and spices. But Raju bhai is a traditionalist. He believes in the clink of coins, not the beep of a phone. A piping hot cup of chai is a steal at just rupee ten, but only if you've got the exact change.

unnormalised: It's not just the smaller vendors either. Even at some "modern" establishments, things can go sideways. Last week, the POS machine at my favourite dosa place went down. Everyone in the queue was scrambling, trying to find an ATM. Luckily, I had a crumpled ₹500 note in my wallet, saved for just such an emergency. Saved the day, I tell you.
normalised: It's not just the smaller vendors either. Even at some "modern" establishments, things can go sideways. Last week, the P-O-S machine at my favourite dosa place went down. Everyone in the queue was scrambling, trying to find an A-T-M. Luckily, I had a crumpled rupee five hundred note in my wallet, saved for just such an emergency. Saved the day, I tell you.

unnormalised: The thing is, I *want* to embrace the cashless future. It’s convenient, it’s efficient, and it reduces the risk of carrying large amounts of cash. But the reality on the ground is often different. Especially in India, where cash is still very much king.
normalised: The thing is, I *want* to embrace the cashless future. It’s convenient, it’s efficient, and it reduces the risk of carrying large amounts of cash. But the reality on the ground is often different. Especially in India, where cash is still very much king.

unnormalised: Maybe someday, UPI will be universally accepted, from the swankiest malls to the humblest street vendors. Maybe someday, I can leave my wallet at home without fear of being stranded.
normalised: Maybe someday, U-P-I will be universally accepted, from the swankiest malls to the humblest street vendors. Maybe someday, I can leave my wallet at home without fear of being stranded.

unnormalised: But until that day arrives, I'll continue to carry a stash of rupees, just in case. My trusty ₹500 note has saved me more times than I care to admit. It's a reminder that progress is not always linear, and sometimes, the old ways are the best ways.
normalised: But until that day arrives, I'll continue to carry a stash of rupees, just in case. My trusty rupee five hundred note has saved me more times than I care to admit. It's a reminder that progress is not always linear, and sometimes, the old ways are the best ways.

unnormalised: So, to all my fellow aspiring digital natives, a word of advice: don’t ditch your cash just yet. You never know when you might need it. And always remember Raju bhai’s chai – it’s worth carrying ₹10 for.
normalised: So, to all my fellow aspiring digital natives, a word of advice: don’t ditch your cash just yet. You never know when you might need it. And always remember Raju bhai’s chai – it’s worth carrying rupee ten for.

unnormalised: After all, who wants to miss out on the best chai in town just because they forgot their wallet? Not me, that’s for sure! And maybe, just maybe, I'll prepone my next trip to the ATM.
